metadata.subject: physics
metadata.dotPoint: investigate and compare theoretically and practically gravitational fields and electrical fields about a point mass or charge (positive or negative) with reference to: the direction of the field, the shape of the field, the use of the inverse square law to determine the magnitude of the field, potential energy changes (qualitative) associated with a point mass or charge moving in the field

gravitational_field_direction.name: Gravitational Field Direction
gravitational_field_direction.correct: Gravitational field lines always point TOWARD the mass creating the field. Gravity only attracts.

away from the mass.error: Reversed. Gravity pulls IN, not out.
away from the mass.fix: Field lines show direction of force on a test mass. Gravity pulls toward the source.
away from the mass.action: Draw a mass and ask: which way would a dropped object fall?

parallel to the surface.error: That's for uniform fields between plates, not point masses.
parallel to the surface.fix: Point masses create radial fields—lines point toward the centre.
parallel to the surface.action: Sketch field lines around Earth. They're radial, not parallel.

in circular paths.error: Confusing field lines with orbital paths.
in circular paths.fix: Field lines are straight and radial. Orbits are curved motion IN the field.
in circular paths.action: Field lines show force direction, not object trajectories.

persistent.gap: You're not visualising gravitational fields correctly.
persistent.action: Draw 10 field line diagrams for point masses. Every line must point inward.

electric_field_direction.name: Electric Field Direction
electric_field_direction.correct: Electric field points AWAY from positive charges and TOWARD negative charges.

toward positive charges.fix: Field direction = direction a POSITIVE test charge would move. Positive repels positive → away.
toward positive charges.action: Place a + test charge near a + source. It's repelled → field points away from source.

away from negative charges.fix: A positive test charge is attracted TO negative → field points toward negative.
away from negative charges.action: Place a + test charge near a − source. It's attracted → field points toward source.

always toward the charge.fix: Electric fields can point either way depending on charge sign. Gravity always attracts.
always toward the charge.action: Key difference: gravity only attracts, electricity attracts AND repels.

persistent.gap: You're confusing electric and gravitational field directions.
persistent.action: Memorise: E-field away from +, toward −. Test with a positive test charge.

radial_field_shape.name: Radial Field Shape
radial_field_shape.formula: Lines spread radially from point source
radial_field_shape.correct: Point masses and point charges create radial fields—lines spread outward (or inward) like spokes of a wheel.

parallel lines.error: Parallel lines are for uniform fields, not point sources.
parallel lines.fix: Point sources create radial patterns. Parallel fields exist between charged plates.
parallel lines.action: Compare: point charge (radial) vs parallel plates (uniform/parallel).

curved lines.error: Field lines from a single point source are straight, not curved.
curved lines.fix: Curved lines appear with multiple sources (dipoles). Single source = straight radial lines.
curved lines.action: Draw field from ONE charge. Lines are straight. Add a second charge—then they curve.

concentric circles.error: Circles show equipotential lines, not field lines.
concentric circles.fix: Field lines are radial. Equipotentials are perpendicular to field lines = circles for point sources.
concentric circles.action: Don't confuse field lines (show force direction) with equipotentials (show constant energy).

persistent.gap: You're confusing field line shapes for different configurations.
persistent.action: Make a table: point source → radial, parallel plates → uniform, dipole → curved.

inverse_square_relationship.name: Inverse Square Law
inverse_square_relationship.correct: Both gravitational and electric field strengths decrease with the SQUARE of distance. Double the distance → quarter the field.

inversely proportional to distance.error: It's inverse SQUARE, not just inverse.
inversely proportional to distance.fix: g ∝ 1/r² and E ∝ 1/r². The exponent is 2, not 1.
inversely proportional to distance.action: Double the distance: field becomes 1/4, not 1/2. Triple → 1/9, not 1/3.

directly proportional to distance.error: Opposite relationship. Field DECREASES with distance.
directly proportional to distance.fix: Further from source = weaker field. It's an inverse relationship.
directly proportional to distance.action: Is gravity stronger or weaker on a mountaintop vs sea level?

independent of distance.fix: Only uniform fields (between parallel plates) are distance-independent. Point sources follow 1/r².
independent of distance.action: Calculate g at Earth's surface vs at 2× Earth's radius. Very different.

proportional to distance squared.error: Inverse, not direct. You dropped the '1 over'.
proportional to distance squared.fix: Field = k/r², not kr². Bigger r in denominator = smaller field.
proportional to distance squared.action: Check the formula: g = GM/r². r² is in the denominator.

persistent.gap: You don't understand inverse square relationships.
persistent.action: Calculate field at r, 2r, 3r, 4r. Verify: 1, 1/4, 1/9, 1/16 pattern.

gravitational_field_formula.name: Gravitational Field Strength Formula
gravitational_field_formula.correct: Gravitational field strength: g = GM/r², where G is the gravitational constant, M is the source mass, r is distance from centre.

g = Gm/r².error: Wrong mass. Use source mass M, not test mass m.
g = Gm/r².fix: The field is created by the SOURCE. g = GM/r² uses the mass creating the field.
g = Gm/r².action: Earth's field doesn't depend on YOUR mass. It depends on Earth's mass.

g = GM/r.fix: Inverse SQUARE law: g = GM/r². The r must be squared.
g = GM/r.action: Check units: G has m² in numerator, so r² in denominator gives N/kg.

g = GMr².error: r² should be in denominator, not numerator.
g = GMr².fix: g = GM/r². Field DECREASES with distance, so r² must be dividing.
g = GMr².action: If r² were in numerator, field would increase with distance. That's wrong.

g = kQ/r².error: That's the electric field formula, not gravitational.
g = kQ/r².fix: Gravitational: g = GM/r². Electric: E = kQ/r². Don't mix G with k, or M with Q.
g = kQ/r².action: G goes with mass (gravity), k goes with charge (electricity).

persistent.gap: You're confusing gravitational and electric field formulas.
persistent.action: Write both: g = GM/r² (gravity, mass) and E = kQ/r² (electric, charge). Compare.

electric_field_formula.name: Electric Field Strength Formula
electric_field_formula.correct: Electric field strength: E = kQ/r², where k is Coulomb's constant, Q is the source charge, r is distance from the charge.

E = kq/r².error: Use source charge Q, not test charge q.
E = kq/r².fix: The field is created by the SOURCE charge. E = kQ/r².
E = kq/r².action: The field exists whether or not a test charge is present.

E = kQ/r.fix: Inverse SQUARE law: E = kQ/r². The r must be squared.

E = GM/r².fix: Electric: E = kQ/r². Gravitational: g = GM/r². k and Q for electricity.
E = GM/r².action: k (Coulomb's constant) pairs with Q (charge). G pairs with M (mass).

E = kQr².fix: E = kQ/r². Field decreases with distance.
E = kQr².action: Stronger field near the charge, weaker far away. That requires r² in denominator.

persistent.gap: You're not secure with the electric field formula.
persistent.action: Calculate E at three distances from a 1 μC charge. Verify 1/r² pattern.

potential_energy_gravitational.name: Gravitational Potential Energy Change
potential_energy_gravitational.formula: Moving away from mass → PE increases
potential_energy_gravitational.correct: Moving a mass AWAY from a gravitational source INCREASES gravitational potential energy. Work must be done against gravity.

decreases.error: Opposite. Moving away from source increases PE.
decreases.fix: You must do work to lift something. That work becomes stored PE.
decreases.action: Lift a ball. You did work. Where did that energy go? → stored as PE.

stays the same.error: PE definitely changes with position in a field.
stays the same.fix: PE depends on position. Different height = different PE.
stays the same.action: A ball on a shelf has more PE than a ball on the floor. Position matters.

becomes zero.error: PE doesn't disappear, it changes value.
becomes zero.fix: PE = 0 only at infinity (by convention). At finite distances, PE is negative for gravity.
becomes zero.action: PE is relative. We set zero at infinity, so all finite distances have negative PE.

persistent.gap: You don't understand how position affects gravitational PE.
persistent.action: Think energy conservation: lift an object → your work → stored as PE. Drop it → PE → KE.

potential_energy_electric.name: Electric Potential Energy Change
potential_energy_electric.correct: For like charges: moving apart DECREASES PE (they repel). For opposite charges: moving apart INCREASES PE (they attract).

always increases when moving apart.fix: Like charges repel → moving apart is 'downhill' → PE decreases. Opposite charges attract → moving apart is 'uphill' → PE increases.
always increases when moving apart.action: Ask: does the system WANT to move this way? If yes, PE decreases.

always decreases when moving apart.fix: Opposite charges attract. Separating them requires work → PE increases.
always decreases when moving apart.action: Pulling apart a + and − is like stretching a spring. Energy stored.

same as gravitational.error: Electric has two cases; gravity only has one.
same as gravitational.fix: Gravity only attracts → always one direction. Electricity can attract OR repel.
same as gravitational.action: Key difference: gravity = always attract. Electricity = attract or repel depending on signs.

persistent.gap: You're not distinguishing between like and opposite charge PE changes.
persistent.action: Make a 2×2 table: like charges moving apart/together, opposite charges moving apart/together. Fill in PE change for each.

field_comparison_forces.name: Gravitational vs Electric Field Comparison
field_comparison_forces.correct: Both follow inverse square law. Key difference: gravity ONLY attracts (masses), electricity can attract OR repel (charges).

electric fields are stronger at all dist.error: Depends on the source values, not inherent property.
electric fields are stronger at all dist.fix: Electrostatic force between elementary charges is stronger than gravitational force between same particles, but field strength depends on source mass/charge.
electric fields are stronger at all dist.action: Compare force formulas. At atomic scale, electric dominates. At planetary scale, gravity dominates.

gravitational fields can repel.error: Gravity ONLY attracts. No negative mass exists.
gravitational fields can repel.fix: There's no 'negative mass' in nature. All masses attract all other masses.
gravitational fields can repel.action: This is a fundamental difference: gravity = only attraction. Electricity = both.

they follow different distance laws.fix: g ∝ 1/r² and E ∝ 1/r². Same mathematical relationship.
they follow different distance laws.action: Compare formulas: g = GM/r², E = kQ/r². Both have r² in denominator.

persistent.gap: You're not clear on similarities and differences between the fields.
persistent.action: Make comparison table: property, gravitational field, electric field. Include: source, formula, direction, attract/repel.

monopole_dipole.name: Monopoles and Dipoles
monopole_dipole.formula: Gravity = monopole only; Electric = monopole or dipole
monopole_dipole.correct: Gravitational monopoles exist (single masses). Electric monopoles exist (single charges). Electric dipoles exist (+ and − pair). No gravitational dipoles (no negative mass).

gravitational dipoles exist.error: No negative mass, so no gravitational dipoles.
gravitational dipoles exist.fix: A dipole requires opposite 'poles'. Gravity has no negative mass → no dipoles.
gravitational dipoles exist.action: Dipole means two opposite things. +/− charges exist. +/− masses don't.

electric monopoles don't exist.fix: A proton is a positive monopole. An electron is a negative monopole.
electric monopoles don't exist.action: You're thinking of magnetic monopoles (which don't exist). Electric monopoles do exist.

magnetic monopoles exist.error: Magnetic monopoles have never been found.
magnetic monopoles exist.fix: Magnets always have N and S poles together = dipoles only. Cut a magnet → two smaller dipoles.
magnetic monopoles exist.action: This question is about gravity and electricity, not magnetism. But note: magnetism = dipoles only.

persistent.gap: You're confusing monopoles/dipoles across field types.
persistent.action: Table: Gravity (monopole only), Electricity (monopole and dipole), Magnetism (dipole only).

potential_energy.instructions: Complete the statements about how potential energy changes in gravitational and electric fields.

comparison.instructions: Complete the statements comparing gravitational and electric fields.

d3.tooltip: Is there such a thing as negative mass?

d4.tooltip: What happens between like charges? Opposite charges?

direction_shape.title: Applying Field Direction Concepts
direction_shape.instructions: Apply your understanding of field direction to these scenarios.

sentences.text: A satellite experiences a gravitational force directed {{d1}} Earth's centre because gravitational fields point {{d2}} the mass creating them.

d1.tooltip: Gravity pulls objects which direction relative to the source?

d2.tooltip: The field shows which way a test mass would accelerate.

sentences.text: A positive test charge placed near a negative source charge will accelerate {{d3}} the source because electric field points {{d4}} negative charges.

d4.tooltip: Field direction = direction a positive test charge would move.

sentences.text: Both point mass and point charge fields have a {{d5}} shape, meaning field lines are {{d6}} and spread outward from the source.

d5.tooltip: Like the spokes of a wheel from the centre.

d6.tooltip: From a single point source, field lines don't bend.

inverse_square.title: Applying the Inverse Square Law
inverse_square.instructions: Apply inverse square law reasoning to these problems.

sentences.text: If you double the distance from a point mass, the gravitational field strength becomes {{d1}} of its original value, because field is proportional to {{d2}}.

d2.tooltip: The denominator has r², not r.

sentences.text: At three times the distance from a point charge, the electric field strength is {{d3}} of the original value, following the pattern E ∝ {{d4}}.

d4.tooltip: Both gravity and electric fields follow this relationship.

sentences.text: To calculate gravitational field at distance r from a planet of mass M, use g = {{d5}}. To calculate electric field at distance r from charge Q, use E = {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: G for gravity, M for source mass, r² in denominator.

d6.tooltip: k for electricity, Q for source charge, r² in denominator.

potential_energy.title: Applying Potential Energy Concepts
potential_energy.instructions: Apply potential energy reasoning to these scenarios.

sentences.text: A rocket moving away from Earth must do work against gravity, so its gravitational PE {{d1}}. If the rocket engines stop, gravity will accelerate the rocket back {{d2}} Earth.

d1.tooltip: Work done against a force is stored as PE.

d2.tooltip: Gravity always pulls toward the mass.

sentences.text: Two electrons held close together have {{d3}} electric PE. When released, they accelerate apart and their PE {{d4}} as it converts to kinetic energy.

d3.tooltip: Like charges repel. Being forced together stores energy.

d4.tooltip: PE converts to KE as charges move in their natural direction.

sentences.text: An electron and proton separated further apart have their electric PE {{d5}} because opposite charges {{d6}} each other.

d5.tooltip: Separating attracting charges requires work → stored as PE.

comparison.title: Comparing Field Behaviors
comparison.instructions: Identify similarities and differences between field types.

sentences.text: The electric field 1 m from a proton follows the same {{d1}} pattern as the gravitational field 1 m from Earth, but the electric field can point {{d2}} from the source if the charge is positive.

d2.tooltip: Gravity always points toward mass. Electric field from + charge points...?

sentences.text: Unlike magnetic sources which only exist as {{d3}}, both point masses and point charges can exist as isolated {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: Cut a magnet in half → two smaller magnets, each with N and S.

d4.tooltip: A single mass or single charge is a...?

sentences.text: When comparing the effect on a proton: Earth's gravitational field causes acceleration {{d5}} Earth, while a negative charge's electric field causes acceleration {{d6}} the charge.

d6.tooltip: Positive proton is attracted to negative charge.

direction_shape.title: Synthesising Field Direction Concepts
direction_shape.instructions: Demonstrate mastery of field direction and shape concepts.

sentences.text: The key reason gravitational field lines only point inward while electric field lines can point either way is that {{d1}} exist but {{d2}} do not.

d1.tooltip: What makes electric fields able to point outward from sources?

sentences.text: Both fields from point sources have {{d3}} symmetry, meaning they look the same from any angle around the source, with strength depending only on {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: The field extends equally in all 3D directions.

d4.tooltip: For a point source, only r matters, not θ or φ.

sentences.text: A positive test charge in an electric field experiences force in the {{d5}} direction as the field vector, while a negative test charge experiences force in the {{d6}} direction.

d5.tooltip: Electric field is DEFINED as force direction on a positive charge.

inverse_square.title: Mastering the Inverse Square Law
inverse_square.instructions: Demonstrate complete understanding of the inverse square relationship.

sentences.text: The physical reason both fields follow inverse square laws is that field lines spread over a {{d1}} that increases with r², so field line density (and thus field strength) decreases as {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: Surface area of a sphere = 4πr². As r increases, lines spread over more area.

d2.tooltip: Same number of lines over larger area → lower density → weaker field.

sentences.text: When comparing formulas g = GM/r² and E = kQ/r², the constant G pairs with {{d3}} while the constant k pairs with {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: G is the gravitational constant. It relates to what property?

d4.tooltip: k is Coulomb's constant. It relates to what property?

sentences.text: At 4 times the original distance, field strength becomes {{d5}} of original. At half the distance, field becomes {{d6}} the original.

potential_energy.title: Mastering Potential Energy
potential_energy.instructions: Demonstrate complete understanding of potential energy in fields.

sentences.text: For gravitational PE: moving away from source {{d1}} increases PE. For electric PE of like charges: moving away {{d2}} PE because the force is repulsive.

d1.tooltip: Gravity only attracts → moving away always fights the force.

d2.tooltip: Like charges WANT to move apart. Natural direction = decreasing PE.

sentences.text: The formula Eg = mgh applies for {{d3}} gravitational fields, while the inverse square formulas apply for {{d4}} gravitational fields.

d3.tooltip: Near Earth's surface, g is approximately constant = uniform field.

d4.tooltip: When g varies significantly with r, the field is non-uniform.

sentences.text: A key insight: PE decreases when an object moves in the direction the field {{d5}} it. Work done by the field converts PE to {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: Moving 'downhill' energetically = with the force = PE decreases.

d6.tooltip: Object speeds up as it falls → gaining KE.

comparison.title: Complete Field Comparison
comparison.instructions: Synthesise your understanding of both field types.

sentences.text: The mathematical similarity (both 1/r²) arises because both fields spread in {{d1}} dimensions from a point source. The physical difference (attract only vs attract/repel) arises because {{d2}} comes in two signs but mass does not.

d1.tooltip: We live in 3D space. Fields spread over spherical surfaces.

d2.tooltip: Positive and negative charge exist. Only positive mass exists.

sentences.text: For gravitational fields, potential energy is always {{d3}} (with zero at infinity) because gravity only attracts. For electric fields, PE can be {{d4}} depending on whether charges are like or opposite.

d3.tooltip: Bound systems have negative total PE. All gravitational systems are bound.

d4.tooltip: Like charges (repelling) → positive PE. Opposite charges (attracting) → negative PE.

sentences.text: Both a single mass and a single charge are called {{d5}}. However, only {{d6}} can form a dipole because it requires opposite 'poles' to exist.

d6.tooltip: You need + and − to make a dipole. Only charge has both.
